title: Security Quiz
description: Quiz covering security concepts, malware, and vulnerabilities.

questions.text: Which type of malware disguises itself as legitimate software?
questions.explanation: A Trojan disguises itself as legitimate, desirable code or software.

questions.text: What is the primary function of a rootkit?
questions.explanation: A rootkit gives malicious actors remote control of a victimâ€™s computer with full admin privileges.
correctAnswers: Provide remote control with admin privileges

questions.text: A worm requires a host file to infect a system.
questions.explanation: A worm targets vulnerabilities in operating systems to install themselves into networks and does not require a host file.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of a virus?
questions.explanation: A virus is a piece of code that inserts itself into an application and executes when the app is run.
wrongAnswers: Provide remote control with admin privileges

questions.text: What is the purpose of Data Execution Prevention (DEP)?
questions.explanation: Data Execution Prevention (DEP): System level memory protection that prevents the execution of data.
correctAnswers: Prevent execution of data in memory

questions.text: Kerberos is an authentication protocol that uses tickets to verify identity.
questions.explanation: Kerberos works on the basis of tickets to allow nodes communicating over a non-secure network to prove their identity to one another in a secure manner.

questions.text: Which of the following is a data integrity tool for monitoring file changes?
questions.explanation: Tripwire is a security and data integrity tool for monitoring and alerting on specific file changes.

questions.text: What is the default port used by Kerberos?
questions.explanation: Kerberos uses UDP port 88 by default

questions.text: Which of the following is a type of cryptography?
questions.explanation: PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) is an encryption program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication.

questions.text: Hashing is a two-way function used to protect data confidentiality.
questions.explanation: Hashing is a one-way function used to ensure data integrity, while encryption is a two-way function used to protect data confidentiality.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of a worm?
questions.explanation: Worms can copy themselves and spread through a network by exploiting security vulnerabilities.
wrongAnswers: Provides remote control with admin privileges

questions.text: What is the purpose of an Intrusion Detection System (IDS)?
questions.explanation: IDS monitors a network or systems for malicious activity or policy violations.

questions.text: An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) is placed out-of-band and passively monitors network traffic.
questions.explanation: IPSs are placed in-line and are able to actively prevent or block intrusions that are detected.

questions.text: Which of the following is a method for detecting rootkits?
questions.explanation: Rootkits may be injected into applications, kernels, hypervisors, or firmware.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Windows File Protection (WFP)?
questions.explanation: Windows File Protection (WFP) prevents the replacement of protected system files.
correctAnswers: Prevent replacement of protected system files

questions.text: A Trojan can replicate itself without user interaction.
questions.explanation: Trojans do not replicate themselves; they rely on user interaction to spread.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common characteristic of botnets?
questions.explanation: Botnets are often used to launch DDoS attacks.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a SIEM system?
questions.explanation: SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) systems aggregate and analyze security logs from various sources.

questions.text: A signature-based antivirus is effective against zero-day exploits.
questions.explanation: Signature-based antivirus software is not effective against zero-day exploits because it relies on known malware signatures.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common method for malware to maintain persistence on a system?
questions.explanation: Malware often modifies startup entries to ensure it runs automatically when the system boots.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key component of the Kerberos authentication process?
questions.explanation: Ticket Granting Tickets (TGTs) are a key component of the Kerberos authentication process, issued by the Authentication Server.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tool used for monitoring and alerting on specific file changes to ensure data integrity?
questions.explanation: Tripwire is a security and data integrity tool for monitoring and alerting on specific file changes on a range of systems.

questions.text: Which type of malware targets vulnerabilities in operating systems to install themselves into networks?
questions.explanation: Worms target vulnerabilities in operating systems to install themselves into networks. Often used to launch DDoS attacks, steal data, etc. Can copy itself and spread through a network by exploiting security vulnerabilities.

questions.text: Which type of malware is a piece of code that inserts itself into an application and executes when the app is run?
questions.explanation: Virus: Piece of code that inserts itself into an application and executes when the app is run.
